metadata.case_name: State of Orissa v. First Respondent

facts.text: First respondent holds B.B.S. from Punjab University, Diploma in Gynecology and Obstetrics from Madras University, Diploma in Obstetrics from Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists of London.

First respondent appointed on June 12, 1938, as Assistant Surgeon in Orissa Medical Service; declared date of birth as April 10, 1910, supported by documentary evidence from father, verified and accepted, recorded in Civil List and History of Service by Accountant General.
Normal superannuation at age 55 on April 10, 1965.

Notification dated May 21, 1963, by State of Orissa raised age of superannuation from 55 to 58 years for Government servants retiring after December 1, 1962; first respondent due to retire on April 10, 1968.
Anonymous letters to Accountant General alleging first respondent misstated age on admission to service.

After inquiry, first respondent required to show cause why date of birth April 4, 1907 should not be accepted; she submitted it was correctly recorded as April 10, 1910, and school record relied on was erased, altered or overwritten.
Letter dated June 27, 1963, by Government of Orissa determined date of birth as April 16, 1907; deemed retired on April 16, 1962, subject to extension till afternoon of July 15, 1963.

First respondent applied to Orissa High Court in O.J.C. No. 254 of 1963 for writ declaring order illegal, against Constitution and natural justice, mala fide; sought mandamus/certiorari quashing June 27, 1963 order, entitled to continue till April 10, 1968.

High Court judgment and order dated May 6, 1964: order amounted to compulsory retirement contrary to service rules, removal under Art. 311 without reasonable opportunity; invalid. Did not decide mala fides as questions of fact not for Art. 226.
In 1957, anonymous letters to Director of Health Services alleging misstated age; no immediate enquiry.

In 1961, Vigilance Department investigation; Secretary Health Dept. on August 23, 1961 informed first respondent of school records suggesting age 15 on Class X admission, 17 years 2 months on First Year Class July 9, 1924; show cause why May 9, 1907 not accepted.
First respondent replied she did not recollect attending Ravenshaw Girls School.
Admission Register examined by first respondent with Director of Health Services and Vigilance officers; on March 19, 1962, she pointed out irregularities in Ravenshaw Girls School entries.
Additional Director Dr. S. Mitra report relied on letter from Principal Lady Hardinge Medical College showing DOB April 4, 1908; shown to first respondent who declined comments.
Notice September 28, 1962 from Health Secretary: Ravenshaw register DOB August 22, 1906; First Year April 1907; intend to treat latter as DOB, show cause.
Four dates before authorities: 1. August 22, 1906 (Ravenshaw); 2. April 1907 (First Year); 3. April 4, 1908 (Lady Hardinge); 4. April 10, 1910 (service record).
Dr. Mitra's report not disclosed to first respondent.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court should have decided disputed questions of fact in a writ petition under Art. 226.
Whether the order refixing the date of birth was an administrative order and High Court had no power to sit in appeal over State authorities.

Whether the order declaring superannuation based on refixed date of birth amounted to compulsory retirement/removal under Art. 311 requiring reasonable opportunity, and violated principles of natural justice.

petitioner_arguments.text: Petition raised disputed questions of fact; High Court should not have decided in writ petition.
Order refixing age was administrative; High Court had no power to sit in appeal over State decision.
Art. 311 has no application as no dismissal/removal; proper superannuation based on true DOB April 16, 1907 after enquiry.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 311; Rule 13 Orissa Civil Services Rules, 1962

respondent_arguments.text: State arbitrarily fixed DOB as April 16, 1907, declared superannuated before age 58; order contrary to law, Constitution, natural justice, mala fide, compulsory retirement violating Art. 311 without opportunity.
School records altered/erased; service record correctly April 10, 1910.

court_reasoning.text: Contentions without substance; under Art. 226, High Court not precluded from facts; discretion to enquire if not complicated; here, question of arbitrary action, no interference with HC discretion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Question was regularity of enquiry, not complicated facts.

court_reasoning.text: No enquiry per Art. 311; but Art. 311 applies as removal/compulsory retirement before superannuation; State not precluded from enquiry on DOB but must follow natural justice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Holder of office right to continue till superannuation under Art. 309 rules; cannot remove except good reasons.

court_reasoning.text: Administrative order involving civil consequences must follow natural justice: inform of case/evidence, opportunity to meet/explain; duty to act judicially implicit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order to prejudice of vested rights must be consistent with justice/fair play.

court_reasoning.text: Enquiry flawed: not all materials (four dates) placed before her; Dr. Mitra report not disclosed; required show cause only on April 16, 1907 without evidence; contrary to basic concept of justice.

holdings.text: High Court has discretion under Art. 226 to decide facts if not complicated; no interference.
Even administrative orders with civil consequences must follow natural justice; duty to act judicially implicit.
Refixing DOB leading to premature retirement is removal requiring Art. 311 opportunity/natural justice; enquiry here violated it.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 226 jurisdiction on facts; Art. 309 service rules; Art. 311 protection against removal without opportunity

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Penalties including compulsory retirement; explanation that superannuation not penalty

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court order upheld setting aside State Government's order of June 27, 1963 refixing date of birth and retiring first respondent prematurely, as it violated natural justice and amounted to invalid removal under Art. 311.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court writ quashing State order upheld

key_quotes.text: An order by the State to the prejudice of a person in derogation of his vested rights may be made only in accordance with the basic rules of justice and fairplay.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle applied to administrative orders

key_quotes.text: If the tails of justice be ignored and an order to the prejudice of a person is made, the order is a nullity. That is a basic concept of the rule of law.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes nullity for violating natural justice

key_quotes.text: Duty to act judicially would therefore arise from the very nature of the function intended to be performed it need not be shown to be super-added.
key_quotes.speaker: court
